comment:
So I must preface this review by saying that when I opened the bottle and took the first taste, all I could think of was how I was going to slam this in my review. It smelled like tea, and tasted like tea, tobacco, and leather. But a funny thing happened as I tasted it during pours and even more so as the bottle reached the halfway point; it morphed into something else and a host of new flavors came out. I have never had a whiskey change this dramatically after first tasting. That said, on to the review:

Nose: Tea, tobacco, and leather (lol) Ok but seriously, in addition to that there's unsweetened chocolate, vinegar, root beer, musty rickhouse, and a savory soy sauce note. 

Palate is a pretty punchy blast of candied orange, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and hazelnut.  Oh also tea, tobacco, and leather. :)  Definitely on the tannic side, but with a surprising amount of complexity which increases with each sip. 

Finish is pretty short with cinnamon, clove, and menthol. More candied orange when that fades. Mouthfeel is light bodied but fits the profile and proof well.

So after thinking I was going to slam the shit out of this, here I am giving it a decent review. I found myself repeatedly coming back to this over and over again to analyze it, and will be sad to see the almost empty bottle go. A weird bird, but at $35 a weird bird worth having around and I will almost certainly buy another bottle.

Nose: Bananas
Palate: Chocolate chip banana bread to a tee
Finish: More of the same, a little short

Easy sipper and nice change of pace

I get a big whiff of caramelized banana and chocolate when I nose the glass.  The flavor on this one is interesting. Its reminiscent of rye, but the spice is muted. The  banana shows up again but this time it tastes more like green bananas. I found the finish to be hot but short.
As others have said, really good drink for a break from bourbon and/or scotch.  Sweet, then some spice, vanilla.  A keeper.

Interesting stuff. Ridiculously smooth. But make note, this is not bourbon. Doesn't taste remotely like bourbon. Somewhere inbetween bourbon and highland malt scotch. I enjoyed it a lot, but I imagine a lot will not.

As a bourbon lover who does like an occasional scotch, I don’t really care for this.  It is smooth, not much of a bite for 90 Proof, but it is not really what I was expecting.  Hard to explain, but if you’re in the mood for bourbon, then just go get a bourbon..... this really is different and not something I will buy again.

On the nose you get distinct notes of honey, toffee, and barley. Rather bright nose with a hint of maple. On the front of the tongue you get some spice and heat with touches of woodiness that follow on to the finish. Buttery transition into mid mouth with a mouthfeel that’s reminiscent of several highland malts made on shorter alembic stills. Starting light and finishing rather dense on the mouthfeel side of things. As you get to the finish, there begins to be a bit of slipperiness on the front of the tongue and you start to perceive the rye in the grain build. Tobacco, malt, rye, and vanilla are all notes you can pick up on a nice finish. Rather impressive for an American malt and certainly worth a pour.
Smells like unbaked bread. Smooth and slightly bitter. Straightforward, very obviously a malt, even if it's a lower mash bill. Maybe some zest at the end. 7/21/18

This bourbon has become a nightly pour for me. Undeniably smooth with notes of caramel and vanilla on the nose. Oak notes on the palate as well as semi sweet chocolate that shines through to the finish with those familiar highland whisky flavors peeking through at the end. Easily my favorite Woodford product to date

Intrigued more by how this morphs from scotch to Bourbon as it finishes.Was impressed by the balance but I'm sure whether Id personally buy a bottle. Purists stay away for both scotch and Bourbon alike!

On the nose there is sweet corn, lots of pleasant malty and cereal notes and a solid showing of oak and vanilla. The palate morphs along the way, crazy! Chocolates, mild vanilla, some baking spices and hint of classic bourbon notes and ends with a hit of cinnamon. The rye feels heavier than 2%. Mouth feel isn't too heavy. Finish is short and leaves something to be desired. Overall, my favorite Woodford offering! Their bourbon hasn't been great the past few years in my opinion, but this is awesome! It'd be a perfect bridge for people interested in traveling/dabbling between bourbon and scotch! Instantly a new favorite!
Simple, full taste. Not too full with any single favor but a nice smooth malt (or barley) aroma. Sweet grass, some barrel. Almost a scotch flavor without the smoke.
alcohol nose, young and sweet. Woodford notes but with more caramel and honey.

When I uncorked this bottle, I was quickly hit with malt and tea leaves. (Not really something I want to smell in a whiskey.) It took some time to find those classic bourbon notes. (Vanilla, honey, caramel).

I gave it a week to open up before I tasted it again. On the nose, I got buttery caramel, a little vanilla, honey, and some oak spice. Those sweet flavors fell onto the palate, along with some dark chocolate bitterness, cinnamon candies, barrel char, and dark fruits. Amazing flavors, smooth entry, and a warm, spicy finish! I’d say this is for bourbon drinkers who want something a tad lighter. This malt is like a fine wine, MUCH better in time! Definitely one to be enjoyed, neat; NO WATER NECESSARY! Good job, Woodford!!!!!!!

Typically a straight bourbon drinker, given that I’ve always loved the Woodford Brand so I figured I’d give this a shot... incredibly smooth! It’s a great whiskey for the first time “neat” drinker... will definetly buy again.

Sweet cinnamon, Spicy vanilla with some salted caramel... I would have a hard time saying this is not a really good bourbon. But it does come off a little sweeter. And More cinnamon apple. All in all very impressed and very good for the money.. $35.00 local. Worth a Try for sure. I might always have a bottle of this on my shelf.

Look: Burnt dark orange, with plenty of lacing on the glass. 

Nose: The nose is really strong on this one, almost exclusively vanilla. 

Taste: The vanilla is there, but there’s much more oak and barrel coming through than the nose would make you think. Some cinnamon pops up as well. 

Finish: There is a good amount of heat on this bourbon, with a hot finish and lingering wood notes. Butter tannins really come through

Overall: By no means a bad whiskey, but not my favorite offering. If you love vanilla and oak, this is for you.
applewood nose. Strong start with a lingering vanilla.
vanilla and malty with heat at the end...I love it!

In comparison to EH Taylor 4 Grain - (yes internet, I know this doesn’t contain wheat) - i think this takes the cake. A. It’s cheaper. 
B. It’s attainable. C. It tastes far more interesting. 

IMO the barley element is nicely integrated - it hugs the other grains rather than sits beside them in your mouth like a 3rd or 4th wheel like EH. The smell is fantastic and I’d take this over regular woodford neat any day. My only complaint is the sweetness- it’s a tad candy esq - but if you’re in the bourbon mood as a scotch drinker, or just want to share a nice pour with less whisky snobbish friends - this is a great buy. 👍🏼
"I tasted the straight rye and bourbon as well. They are all great sipping whiskeys, but this was the smoothest. Very enjoyable!"

Smells incredible. you smell it all, malt, rye, vanilla, butterscotch. kitchen sink in one sitting. Vanilla creaminess on the palate. heat towards the end on the front of the tongue. Fruity finish. splendid!
Unique sweetness of a heavy malt bill, same proof point as other Woodford bottles. Could make an interesting cocktail
Light, sweet. Some nuttiness. I like it

Dessert - holiday appropriate for a “non-sweet” eater or drinker - chocolate, rich, delicate vanilla.  Easy to reach for a second- and a complete departure from the Woodford collection. If given as a gift, realize you were considered and contemplated over by the giver.  Not for everyone, but everyone will have more than one.
Chocolate, cinnamon, pear, tapioca, musty. Something different each time I go back for a whiff. Waffle cone, caramel, oak, soy sauce, and more chocolate flavors present. Malty and complex
MB: 51/47/2 malt/corn/rye. Barrel char #4?. (Brown Forman Woodford Reserve). The malt overpowers the other flavors, and smells odd. This reminds me of a cheap blended scotch.

Nose - maple syrup, vanilla, chocolate notes, with a hint of oaky spice. Also some toast/cereal grain. Got better and better as it opened up in the glass.

Taste - Everything promised on the nose comes through on the palate. Definitely on the sweeter side, but there's enough going on to keep it from being one-note. Vanilla and oak continue on the somewhat short finish.

This is the best thing Woodford put out, period. It tastes like a wheated bourbon without the cereal notes. If you like Weller, Rebel or Larceny you will like this. I get no single malt notes. It is on the sweeter side, so if you like spice pass on this one. 3.5/5

On the nose, the first thing that this whiskey tells me is to not forget that just because it’s mostly malt, it’s still American. The classic American sweetness and wood notes hit you in the nose. But, one thing you do remember is that this isn’t bourbon. It has a lighter and fruitier nose. Banana is the prominent fruit in this whiskey that jumps out at me. This whiskey is very smooth. The wood notes attack at first, but they give way to beautiful floral notes. It’s like eating a banana in a flower garden. I’m a big fan of Scotch and you can sense some of the note similarities because of the malted barley. For people who want something different and can’t decide between scotch and bourbon, go for this and you won’t be disappointed.
This was a surprise. Flavor of pine nuts on the finish very creamy of sorts.

Burnt sugar and plum on the nose. Vanilla forward followed by Tobacco leaf, raisins and plum with a little oak  in there for good measure. Nice Finish, short to medium. Very smooth with almost no burn.

the nose is kind of bready with maybe some hazelnut spread.  taste is interesting, spicy vanilla from the barrels, with a medium light finish that is a bit shortbread like.  it's kind of like high West campfire if it had a speyside scotch instead of islay
Gene and Diana’s. Sat on the porch with Gene and Matt sampling whiskey and having a great time. This was our first (after dinner).

Nose: cherry and vanilla with sweet red candies and caramel.  Nuts come through but I was eating peanuts so I’m not sure. Red licorice. 

Body: light. I wonder if my bottle being over 5yrs old might adversely effect taste but body wise was thin and smooth. 

Palate: oak, vanilla, toffee

Finish: not long more nuts and light caramel and toffee. 

Note: it’s light, very mildly spicy, thin and perhaps watery. Flavors I fear are a little washed out perhaps from the bottle being old. Still it’s good but I want a new bottle to try again.
The nose is a sweet cherry coke, and the flavors starts like a Irish Whiskey (short-bread cookie, but turns sharply towards the bottom of a chocolate cream pie.
Tastes like Grandpa and Grandma's house in the Autumn. Familiar, sweet, warm, and inviting. Nothing spectacular, but it doesn't need to be. Nostalgia in a glass at a great price.
This is not good. Must be too young. Quite bitter and corny

I thought this was a great whiskey. Sweet, but I won't pretend to say that I tasted pudding, nuts, or maple syrup. I don't know what everyone else is talking about, all I taste is whiskey. 

Smooth and not pretentious. And excellent value.
Just a little too tannic for my palate

Sweet, maple syrup nose
Hot and woody on the tongue 
Sweet, nutty finish
Kind of sweet. Had a good spice to it. Very different from scotch malts, but definitely had a sweetness and richness coupled with a spice from charred barrels
Not real sweet great finish, definitely better than regular  Woodford

A welcome change from both bourbon and scotch. Has a vinegary first taste, but like the high end vinegar you can taste enjoyably. The malt is noticeable with a subtle chocolate note. Has a thick mouth feel, not thin at all.
Chocolate nose, rich flavors and clean finish.
Smooth.   Nothing outstanding but a reliable sipper or mixer

Drammers club online pour. Very good.


Nose: Honey, Citrus, Cereal, Caramel, Banana Bread, Cherry, Apple, Cinnamon, Dark Chocolate, Brown Sugar, Vanilla, Flowers, Root Beer

Palate: Pepper, Honey, Caramel, Vanilla, Dried Fruit, Cherry, Apricot, Coffee, Oak, Banana

Finish: Honey, Caramel, Pepper, Cinnamon, Vanilla
Smooth, nutty and malty at a reasonable price.

Woodford is classy. It’s just really well made. This is like visiting someone’s home you know well, but they’ve done some redecorating. 

Nose: Oak first, then pudding - maybe banana pudding, cherry coke as well

Taste: Honey, milk chocolate, spice and pepper, little minty

Beautiful with a short, oak spice finish
Candied walnuts and pears in the nose, super smooth and slightly smoky on the tongue, clean finish. Definitely a sipping whiskey.

WOODFORD RESERVE STRAIGHT MALT
APPEARANCE: Put to the light, it's a nice shade of dried tobacco. A quick swirl makes slow forming and slow moving fat droplets.
NOSE: Whoa! That Brown Foreman fresh Latex Paint note jumps right out of the glass, but it fades quickly. I get Smoky/Toasty Malt Notes of Dark Chocolate, Raw Almonds,  and Coffee. There is also Black Pepper, Clove, and the smell of Fresh Cut Lumber. (Side note: I only got the Latex Paint note on the first pour)
NEAT: Slightly Oily/Coating Mouthfeel. Lots of Oak here, but the toasted Malt Notes dominate yielding hints of an Extra-Hoppy Beer, with bolder notes of Cashews, Dark Chocolate, Unsweetened Toasted Coconut, Dried Cherries, and Burnt Sugar. A drying finish with Slightly Bitter Oak and Malt coating the palate. 
SPLASH: Gives the nose and palate a a dominant note of Tea Leaves. Reduces the Bitter Oak and adds a mint note. Am I also picking up some Honey Butter?
VERDICT: I am not a huge fan of Woodford in general, but I do applaud their willingness to go out on a limb and try new/different things. Some, like this one, work for me. Others? Well more on that in a future review. I think this is priced just right at $35 ($5 less than their bourbon sells for here). I have liked each successive pour more than the last. It definitely will be a repeat buy.

Definitely an interesting whiskey.
The nose is a bit musty with, vanilla, oak, and spice.  The palate has cocoa, oak, nuts, and lots of malt.  The finish is not overly long with more nuts and dry wood.

All in all, this whiskey is on the drier side, probably due to being malt instead corn based.
A little different from your Bourbon.  Not bad

Nose is fresh banana bread. That's the whole picture for me. Sweet and heavy bread, banana, vanilla, baking spice, raisin. Taste follows the same, sweet bread, banana, vanilla, walnut, chocolate, raisin. Rich, buttery, and so smooth. This has been one of my favorite easy-drinking go-to's. It's simple, consistent, and thoroughly enjoyable.

I've seen a lot of hate from bourbon enthusiasts, and if you're looking for a bourbon, this is not that. It's not like a single malt either. It's a weird hybrid beauty. For 38, I'd do it again.
Sweet up front. Heat kicks in and then slowly mellows out to vanilla and pepper?
I enjoy this cocoa and leather flavors. With the undertones of nuts coming through on the back end. Not peanuts, more walnuts and pecans
